lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write words and sentences clearly and accurately (e.g. What's this?).
supportStrategies: (Writing) On the board, trace “What’s this?” slowly. Students copy in air, then trace in notebooks with support.
stretchStrategies: Start a “Classroom Object Detective” game. Describe one object without saying its name: “It’s long. It’s on the table. It’s for writing.” Students guess and use full sentences to ask: “Is it a pencil?” Give them turns to lead and describe too.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and select the correct classroom item from spoken descriptions.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say clues slowly: “It’s big. It’s on the wall. It’s white.” Students point to the correct object in their SB.
stretchStrategies: Start a “Classroom Object Detective” game. Describe one object without saying its name: “It’s long. It’s on the table. It’s for writing.” Students guess and use full sentences to ask: “Is it a pencil?” Give them turns to lead and describe too.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to play a competitive game.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Collaboration) Group students. One describes an item from the SB, others race to find and point to it. Then switch roles.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
